section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Big Book: How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Jane Yolen and illustrated by Mark Teague
section-block.rac_book_summary: In this fun picture book, dinosaurs seem to do everything dangerous, but soon they are modeling safe ways to behave.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: healthy me | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_body-text: Explain to children that this book features dinosaurs, but they don’t act like dinosaurs. Say: Let’s find out how these dinosaurs act.
Invite children to sing to the tune of “Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush.” “What are some ways that we stay safe?” (Repeat twice). “We’ll learn some ways this morning.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe?, written by Jane Yolen and illustrated by Mark Teague.
Scout can’t wait to read a narrative, or story, that shows dinosaurs learning about safety!
This is a question I want you to think about as you read. We will talk about it after you read. Ready?
What are some ways to stay safe in your home?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at the picture. What is this dinosaur doing? Is he being safe?
Should dinosaurs jump on beds?
Is the dinosaur being safe
Why does the dinosaur’s mother tell it “no” when it’s running down the stairs? What happens to the dinosaur?
Why do you have to be careful when you use forks, knives, and spoons?
Look at the dinosaur in the pool. How does he stay safe when swimming?
What is the dinosaur doing outdoors? What are the boys doing?
The dinosaur is not afraid, so it gives a big roar!”
Let’s all pretend to be dinosaurs and give our best dinosaur roars!
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What are some ways to stay safe in your home?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 students with Equity Sticks to share responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Be careful with forks and knives.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about how to stay safe as children watch and listen. Show children how you begin writing on the left side and add letters and words to the right.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What should we not jump on?
We should not j________ (jump) on beds.
We should not jump on beds.
Why is it not a good idea to jump on beds?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: When words in different languages share similar spelling and meaning, they are cognates. Spanish and English share many cognates; pointing them out can help English learners in the classroom. The English word dinosaur has the Spanish cognate dinosaurio. Both mean “terrible lizard” and come from modern Latin.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: healthy me | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Develop Empathy
section-block.rac_body-text: Review with children the importance of following rules and routines in the classroom. Discuss what it means to think about and identify other people’s feelings. Talk about how caring about each other helps us keep each other safe.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look for the Mind Builder develop empathy as we revisit the book How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe?, written by Jane Yolen and illustrated by Mark Teague
This book shows lots of dinosaurs. Clifford loves dinosaurs!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages of the story to notice the develop empathy Mind Builder in action.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s remember today’s Mind Builder, develop empathy. Look at the picture. How do you think the mother feels as she sees the dinosaur in the road? (MB)
How can the dinosaur make his mother feel better? Can you name a rule the dinosaur is breaking?
How do you think the father in this picture feels? What is the dinosaur doing? Can you name a rule the dinosaur is breaking? (MB)
How do you understand how the mother in this picture feels?
What rule is the dinosaur following to stay safe? (MB)
How do you think they would feel on a long hike without water? Why is making it routine to bring water on a hike important? (MB)
Why is the mother in this picture teaching the dinosaur to call 9-1-1? How can you help others when you need to call 9-1-1?

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to use empathy as they follow the rules to play an acting game. Invite children to form a circle. Choose one child and whisper a simple emotion into his or her ear, such as angry, happy, or sad. That child goes into the circle and tries to show that emotion with his or her face and body. Let other children take turns guessing the emotion. Once a child has guessed it correctly, that child takes the next turn acting out an emotion.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about empathy and how to stay safe. As they speak, encourage children to build on simple sentences by adding phrases that describe.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Showing empathy is a skill that can be developed like many others. Children need to be able to identify others’ emotions and then imagine feeling that way themselves. They should also think about what they can do to help, and what they would want and need if they felt the same way. Discussing pictures and stories can help them develop these skills. (Dewar, 2017)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: healthy me | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_body-text: Explain to children that listening and remembering will help them as they sort things.
Sing to the tune “The Farmer in the Dell.” “We can stay safe. (repeat) We’ll learn about the ways today. We can stay safe.” Add rules, such as “We don’t stand up on chairs.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book, How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? written by Jane Yolen and illustrated by Mark Teague.
Scout loves How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? because it shows dinosaurs having fun inside and outside. Can you find the little words in inside? how about in outside?
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
What are some ways to stay safe outside?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at the picture. Is the dinosaur inside or outside? Is it safe to climb on the ladder?
How could wearing a helmet make the dinosaur safer?
How does this dinosaur stay safe? Why is it important not to go with strangers, or people you don’t know?
How is the dinosaur staying safe in the pool? Why is it important to stay where an adult can see you?
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? Let’s see how much you remember as we talk about the guiding question:
What are some ways to stay safe outside?
section.rac_body-text: Give one moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Wear a helmet when you ride a bicycle.
Stay where an adult can see you.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about how to stay safe. Encourage children to use frames like these to include personal and possessive pronouns in their sentences: I can wear my h____ (helmet) when I r___ (ride) my bike. When I swim, I can stay where an adult can s___ (see) me.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you need to wear when you ride a bicycle?
You need to wear a h______ (helmet) when you ride a bicycle.
You need to wear a helmet when you ride a bicycle.
How can you be safe when you cross a street?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children naturally begin to notice what is the same and what is different in their world. Encouraging this kind of categorizing is an important part of early education, helping children define and organize their world. Support children as they notice similarities and differences based on factors like color and shape of objects.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: healthy me | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about all they have learned about health this month and safety this week. How can they stay safe?
Have fun with children, leading them to try different ways to jump five times. Lead them to try up and down jumps, hops on one legs, and simple jumping jacks.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to read Five Little Froggies Jumping on the Bed. It is a rhyming story on a poster.
Scout loves to look at fun posters of stories and rhymes. Scout can’t wait to start!
How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe? and Five Little Froggies Jumping on the Bed focus on safety. Let’s see if we can find any connections between the two texts.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
How can we protect ourselves and our bodies?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Safe and Sound
section.rac_body-text: Read the poem on the poster together, then use these prompts to read and discuss the poster.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can point to the picture that shows all of the little froggies on the bed? What are the froggies doing? Are they being safe?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Revisit jumping and little Vocabulary Cards.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can point to the picture that shows four froggies on the bed and one on the floor? What happened to the one froggy?
Why do you think the doctor said not to jump on the bed?
What is this dinosaur doing that’s like what the froggies do? Is the dinosaur being safe? What might happen to the dinosaur?
section.rac_d-hed_prompt: No more froggies jumping on the bed
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What lesson do the froggies learn? How can they protect themselves and their bodies?

section.rac_body-text: Have children act out the chant, pretending to be the little froggies jumping on the bed. When you come to “one fell down,” point to a child; that child will sit. Adjust the number to include all children in the class.
Provide a writing prompt about staying safe and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Teaching children common rhyming chants and songs is fun for children, and it is also helps them develop an awareness of rhythm, rhyme, and the sounds of syllables and words. This awareness serves as a foundation for associating sounds with letters as they learn to read.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: healthy me | WEEK 4: Safe and Sound

section-block.rac_body-text: Encourage children to listen by playing “Red Light, Green Light.” Divide class into groups if there are too many children to play safely together; let groups take turns playing. When you say “Green light,” children walk (not run) toward the finish line. When you say “Yellow light,” they walk slowly, and when you say “Red light,” they stop. The game ends when all players have reached the finish line.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book How Do Dinosaurs Stay Safe?
This rhyming book shows how to be safe. Scout loves rhymes!
This week we read about how dinosaurs stay safe. As we read one more time, picture yourselves in the book instead of dinosaurs and think about this question:
What did you learn from the dinosaurs about staying safe?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the big book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The dinosaur is standing on one foot. Does it look like he is being safe? Would it be better if he were standing on two feet?
section.rac_body-text: Explain that instead of two “foots” we say two “feet.”
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Some forks and knives can be sharp. Pretend to eat like this dinosaur. How will being careful with a fork and knife help keep you safe?
When swimming with friends, the dinosaur is careful to be in the right spot where papa can see him.
Why is it important to be in a spot where papa can see him?
The dinosaur always takes bottles of water when he goes on a long hike.
How would you feel after a long hike? Why would you need water?
Why do you think this dinosaur looks so happy? Can you show that feeling?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did you learn from the dinosaurs about staying safe?
section.rac_body-text: Give children a moment to Turn and Talk. Then pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Do not run down the stairs.
Be careful when I cross the street.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about how to stay safe and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is it safe to stand on a chair?
It is not s____ (safe) to stand on a chair.
It is not safe to stand on a chair.
What are things you can do to be careful when you are crossing a street?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: As children begin to write, invite them to write in the language they use at home. Then share these works on bulletin boards to encourage children’s expression. It will also be helpful to students to pair them with other students who speak their language, if possible.
